conclusion: Analyze motion and interactions between vehicles A and B based on power, collision, and deflection.
Vehicle A is on the left side of the image, moving towards the right.
Vehicle B is on the right side of the image, moving towards the left.
Both vehicles are moving in the same direction but towards each other.
As the vehicles approach each other, they will collide.
Collision will cause change in velocities and directions due to conservation of momentum and nature of collision.
Power of vehicles is not given, but they have kinetic energy due to motion.
In inelastic collision, some kinetic energy is converted to other forms and objects stick together.
In elastic collision, total kinetic energy is conserved and objects bounce off each other.
In Image 2, vehicles are in collision, with changed positions and orientations.
In Image 3, vehicles are further apart, indicating continued movement after collision.
Collision is likely inelastic, resulting in vehicles sticking together or stopping.
Final positions in Image 3 suggest collision was not perfectly inelastic, with some kinetic energy transferred to environment.
Final positions of vehicles A and B can be determined based on observations and principles of motion and collision.
In Image 3, vehicle A is further to the right, and vehicle B is further to the left.
Final positions: Vehicle A is on the right side, and Vehicle B is on the left side.
